MainClaim.text: "Malabou's book What Should We Do With Our Brains? offers a critique of neuronal ideology and a call for a new understanding of the brain's plasticity as the production of the new."

Untitled 1.text: "Malabou's project bears a resemblance to Kant's critical project

Untitled 2.text: "The question of freedom has been inverted since Kant

Untitled 3.text: "Malabou's analysis of freedom and neuroscience is organized around the fundamental concept of plasticity."

Untitled 4.text: "Malabou's book links the question of freedom with the structure of the brain

Untitled 5.text: "The discovery of the plasticity of the brain reflects the structure of capitalism and points the way for a conception of the production of the new."

Untitled 6.text: "Malabou's critique of neuronal ideology is that it naturalizes the capitalist demand for flexibility and ignores the possibility of transformative effects on others."

Untitled 7.text: "Malabou's answer to the question 'What should we do with our brain?' is that we should understand plasticity as the production of the new

Untitled 8.text: "Malabou's book offers a call for a new understanding of the brain's plasticity as the production of the new

Untitled 9.text: "Malabou's critique of neuronal ideology is a critique of the fundamental concepts of the neurosciences

Untitled 10.text: "Malabou suggests that the brain's plasticity can move in one of two directions: either it can constitute the biological justification of a type of economic

Untitled 11.text: "Malabou's critique of neuronal ideology is a critique of the naturalization effect of neuroscience

Untitled 12.text: "Malabou argues that the plasticity of the brain can resist the flexibility demanded of it by capitalism

Untitled 13.text: "Malabou's book offers a critique of the fundamental concepts of the neurosciences

Untitled 14.text: "Malabou suggests that the brain's plasticity can be seen as a model for a conception of the production of the new
